Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Nail Bed Repair with or without Fingernail Replacement in Children

Trial_Design.evidence: This multicentre, two-arm, 1:1 parallel-group superiority RCT was conducted across 20 UK hospitals.

Participants.evidence: Participants were children under 16 years with a nail bed injury requiring surgical repair.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group had the fingernail replaced, while the control group had it discarded.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of nail bed repair with versus without fingernail replacement.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The co-primary outcomes were surgical-site infection at 7–10 days and cosmetic appearance at 4–12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 451 children were randomised between July 2018 and December 2019, with 224 in the nail-discarded group and 227 in the nail-replaced group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 218 and 222 participants, respectively, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference was found in infection rates (OR 2.49, 95% CI 0.58 to 10.61; p = 0.218) or cosmetic appearance (p = 0.118).

Harms.evidence: Two serious adverse events were reported, one in each group.

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the UK National Institute for Health Research.
